messages.text:
does anyone actually use julia in CentOS 6?  I'm trying to install Yggdrasil ccache in the docker image of CentOS 6, but
```[root@a0dc056fc7db /]# ccache 
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.18' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `CXXABI_1.3.5' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.14' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.17' not found (required by ccache)
ccache: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found (required by ccache)```
it comes with libstdc++ corresponding to gcc 4.4.7, which is even much older than our oldest version of GCC

I'm confused with one thing...
Musl C and glib C....
If both compile for the same architecture.... example x86_64 linux

They're just different libc implementations, not compilers.....

Why compile with both musl C and glibc?

messages.text:
I am slightly confused by the `dont_dlopen` flag now: I think at some point I added it to our `LibraryProduct`s because the auditor would refuse them otherwise. But at julia-runtime in the jll the library was loaded fine. Now it seems `dont_dlopen` also affects the resulting `_jll` and the library is not loaded anymore which causes another jll that depends on it to fail to load as this one doesn't have `dont_dlopen`.
I get the following error (the corresponding version is yanked now):
```julia> using polymake_jll
julia> using libpolymake_julia_jll
ERROR: InitError: could not load library "/software/julia/depots/julia-153/artifacts/eb5cd45d7e62284ad0eaba0329c8319989a22c4d/lib/libpolymake_julia.so"
libpolymake.so.4.3: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory```
`libpolymake_julia_jll` depends on `polymake_jll` (which provides `libpolymake.so` but with `dont_dlopen`)
dlopen'ing that library manually with the full path (`polymake_jll.libpolymake_path`) does work fine though.
Any suggestions?

messages.text: Is it kosher to specify a symbolic link as the library product in a `build_tarballs.jl`? Microsoft's SEAL produces `libsealc.so.3.6.2` as a file and has `libsealc.so.3`, `libsealc.so.3.6` and `libsealc.so.3.6.2` point on it (or each other). I was thus wondering if it is ok to actually just name the symbolic link `libsealc.so` as the product, as otherwise the product needs to be changed with each new release (which wouldn't be such a huge issue either, I guess).
